pullRequest.body:
The file previously conflated initial segments and their embeddings. Our docstrings are now more careful about the distinction.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [5117d993e8](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15874/commits/5117d993e8c719f51cc1ec462050b5fa06b99802)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

> Where did you get that "initial segment" vs "initial segment embedding" terminology from? This is certainly not how we call things in combinatorics. cc @b-mehta

What do you mean? The corrected changes in this PR look reasonable to me.
There is no such thing as an "initial segment embedding" in my combinatorics lecture notes

Indeed, initial segments are a set theory / ordinals notion that was imported to combinatorics, with the same meaning. This file talks about embeddings which are initial segments, not about initial segments. As such, it shouldn't have the name initialSeg - as Violeta correctly points out in the PR description - and this makes it _more_ consistent with your notes.

In pen and paper set theory, the way you generally work with initial segments is that you talk about a well-order being isomorphic to an initial segment of another, by which you mean a downwards-closed set under the same relation. 

Mathlib's notion of an "initial segment embedding" might be ad-hoc, but it's nicer to work with since it avoids the intermediate `Subrel`.
Drafting this until #17481 goes through, at which point I can spell the fact that the range of `InitialSeg` is in fact an initial segment.
In fact, I think this PR might have done too much... I'll open separate PRs for most of the other changes and keep only the stuff on documentation here.
Where did you get that "initial segment" vs "initial segment embedding" terminology from? This is certainly not how we call things in combinatorics. cc @b-mehta
I would highly suggest you do not introduce these lemmas

Why not? Admittedly this typeclass is a bit strange and specific, but it's satisfied by `IsWellOrder` which does see use in Mathlib. Using these lemmas also simplifies the construction of `collapse` a bit.

`Init.Algebra.Classes` is an ancient file. Almost every declaration in here is deprecated and the file itself will soon be deleted. `IsStrictTotalOrder` too is ancient and we don't want to be adding any new lemma for it.

This file uses the `IsWellOrder` typeclass extensively, and ordinals themselves are defined using `IsWellOrder`. I'm not opposed to getting rid of it, but when that inevitably happens, there's going to be a lot of fallout around this area. So maybe these lemmas can be cleaned up as part of that?

I can remove the unused `trans_lt_le` and move `trans_le_lt` to this file, with a docstring note explaining that at some point we need to refactor it out.
Well what you replace `IsStrictTotalOrder` by `IsWellOrder` in your new lemmas?
Alright, I moved them to the `RelClasses` file and stated them for `IsWellOrder`.

Your sentence is technically true but misleading. Instead of explaining what the definitions are equivalent to in the well-order case, it should give the general definitions, namely
```suggestion
An initial segment is simply a lower set. A principal segment is a set of the form `Set.Iic x` for some `x`.
```
`Set.Iio`, not `Set.Iic`. I've updated the descriptions of `InitialSeg` and `PrincipalSeg` with your suggestion in mind.

While "lower set" is a common enough term in order theory, I think we should still have something like the old description giving a quick explanation of the term. This saves the reader looking it up, and more importantly reassures that the term we use is the same as the informal one! (as you've just seen, that's not always the case in mathlib ;) )

We write `lower set` here, but this doesn't use the predicate [IsLowerSet](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/UpperLower/Basic.html#IsLowerSet). We should either
a) use the existing definition
b) prove the existing definition is equivalent to this and reference that proof in this docstring
c) give an alternative informal description

The choice is yours :)
We can't use `IsLowerSet` since this is for an arbitrary relation, and `IsLowerSet` requires `‚â§`. But morally, that's what it should be.
Good point - that rules out a) but giving the special case for orders would work for b), and c) is my preferred one anyway

Working with initial and principal segments with `<` is somewhat annoying, and it often requires writing the types explicitly like `((¬∑ < ¬∑) : Œ± ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí Prop) ‚âºi ((¬∑ < ¬∑) : Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ≤ ‚Üí Prop)`. I think that issue should probably be fixed before we introduce any API for this special case.

Do I just copy the description from the structure docstring? The "whenever `b < f a` in `Œ≤` then..." bit.
Actually, I will introduce the `IsLowerSet` version of this in a separate PR. That way we can use "proper" vocabulary and have it be right!
Two months later, and we now have [`InitialSeg.isLowerSet_range`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/InitialSeg.html#InitialSeg.isLowerSet_range).
I don't like the variable name `top` here, especially because this probably won't be the top element of the order
I'm compelled to agree, but I'm not sure what a good replacement might be.
I think just `x` should be okay here - everything else is already a single-letter name in this context
Didn't we discuss changing the definition to make this literally true? Or am I misremembering the conclusion

This can't be done as `IsLowerSet` is defined in terms of an order relation, while `InitialSeg` is stated in terms of an arbitrary relation.

However, we do already have `InitialSeg.isLowerSet_range` for initial segments between `<` in a preorder and `<` in a partial order.
Is this change needed in this PR? If not, I'd suggest leaving it out of this one and doing it elsewhere, for a cleaner diff.
This isn't needed here, I'll put it in another PR.
This is now #20413.

pullRequest.title: doc(Order/InitialSeg): Improve documentation
